description.text: I needed a D shaft on Stepper motors for Extruder drive gears belt Drive gears. Here is the BIQ tool I made to cut, File, Grind my D shafts.

Laser cut the parts screw the 4 parts together/  
Fit a stepper motor fit the round dust Gard to the shaft.  
Important: You must now connect / Short all of the Stepper motor wires together. (This Stops the motor from turning)   
I use a Chocolate block/Screw terminal block to make sure they do not become disconected while cutting the D shaft.  
Then mount in a vice to file, dremel or grind the D shape on the shaft

Update 10th april 2016
Added New Z-left, middle and right and 2 new versions of the motor bracket: one with and one without the Z-max endstop holder.
They are all denoted v1.2
Changes:
  • Reduced the depth/length of the "wings" going out backwards as they could hit the z-max endstop holder and/or screws in some instances (not tested on printed cases).
  • Made room for 20mm M4 screws and generally slightly tweaked the middle piece.
  • Rounded a lot of corners and added he Ultius and M4 text to the middle piece.
    • Might come later
    I have thought about making a set for M3 screws.
I made this last year for my Tantillus. I call it an Ultius, as it sort of ended up looking and working bit like an Ultimaker, so Tantillus + Ultimaker = Ultius :)

When using an E3D Volcano I have around 12cm of Z-height! If you use J-head or normal E3D you are going to get substantially more Z-height!
The arms for the bed has been trimmed down a lot to make more Z-height Space. Endstops: I have made it possible to adjust the max-endstop. The MAX endstop can be adjusted using the slides to the left of the motor Mount.
I had my arduino+ramps at the bottom and needed to make sure there was room for it.
If you use MAX-endstop as homing you no longer have to contend with the nozzle dipping Down in plastic when homing.

I used a TR8*8(p2) lead screw and there are holes to Mount the NUT to the middle part
I used *6 psc m4 screws and locking-screws to put the Z-axis parts together, but I guess you can use whatever you find... or just glue it.
Used M5 screws and lockingnuts to Mount the entire axis to the frame.
You need some rather long M3 screws for the Lead-screw nut.

You do need to drill some new holes to Mount this. Might want to make the holes a tad larger to make room for adjustment
Mount it as straight as you can... tighten it almost down then run the axis up and Down to make sure it runs without problems.. then straighten it down. Take your time doing this.

Assembly: if possible I recommend installing the Z-stage with the case disassembled as it will make it much easier to make it run smoothly.
Endstop I'll recommend using the MAX endstop for homing instead of MIN endstop.
When using MIN endstop for homing the nozzle dips Down into molten plastic when homing, and can drag this plastic along onto the print.
Using MAX to home you solve this issue. It is imperative you adjust Z-heigh precizely when using this method.
New slides: I'll recommend taking a look at my new Tantillus Compact Ultimaker Slider Adapters
Corners: also take a look at my Tantillus top corners w. room for spacers

Printer:

Tantillus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

25

Notes: You shouldn't need supports, but you might. Use 2-3 perimeters. Print in ABS if you want to use heated chamber.

Tinkercad I imported some of the original STL files from Tantillus and rewamped them. Others I did from scratch. I can't honestly remember where I got my ideas or how much is completely my own ideas, but I know the Tantillus A2 inspired me some. As you can see I have used both aluminium and acrylic plates. At first I printed straight on Acrylic with nice result for both abs and pla, but I wanted to try heated plate, so cut up some aluminium plate and attached a silicone heating element. Worked great.

Z-height When using an E3D Volcano I have around 12cm of Z-height! If you use J-head or normal E3D you are going to get substantially more Z-height!
The arms for the bed has been trimmed down a lot to make more Z-height Space which was my main goal for this design, apart from the lead-screw option.

Simple container for organizing M3 screws. Placing a screw beside each compartment makes it really easy to find, or put in, the correct length screw in the correct compartment.

This is a pen holder designed for a Norland Research Calculator Controlled Robot: http://www.smallrobot.com/ It is sized to work with a standard full-size Crayola marker ~14.5mm diameter. There is a bridge between the clamp and the base which acts as a spring hinge to keep pen pressure consistent across bumps and dips. ~15 min print on MakerBot #322

Skein, (or use my gcode)
Print,
Use: Use it in conjunction with a robot to draw things. Draw shapes on large sheets of paper. Circles are easy Or use it as a pen holder wherever you need to hold a pen.

title: Scalar - Upgrade Z Axis trapezoïdal screw

description.text:
This thing is a mechanical upgrade for Scalar XL 3D printers.
This upgrade allows to use a Tr8x1.5 trapezoïdal leadscrew instead of a standard M8 leadscred on Z Axis. For the convertion, as the Trapezïdal leadcrew often requires a special nut, the Leadscrew has to be moved a little bit, for the nut to fit the overall design of the Scalar XL.

• 2016.07.28 - Added Nut holder for T8 nuts
  • 2016.07.15 - Both tops and Bottom holders have been upgraded
  • 2016.07.15 - Motor holder for 8mm smooth rods has also been corrected, the 435mm smooth rods were too short. This was fixed, the motor holder can now support 435mm rods.

So you wil need to print
  • The bottom Z axis motor holders
  • The Top Z axis smooth rod holders
    • For Scalar XL:
  • The X axis moto holder 10mm
  • The X axis Idler holder 10mm
    • For Scalar M:
  • The X axis moto holder 8mm
  • The X axis Idler holder 8mm
• Nut adaptor for M8 or TR08X1.5 Hex Nut http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1379340
• Top_Z_Holder 8mm.stl is reversible, so you can use it for both right and left side of the printer.

We uploaded 2 Gcodes
  • ConfigTR08x1.5.gcode that allows you to reconfigure the firmware settings of your printer with the proper Zstep/mm (2133.33 compatible with TR08x1.5)
  • ConfigM8.gcode Capable of setting back the Z step/mm (2550) for M8 threaded rod

• Igus polymere nut :http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/linear-motion/123-hex-nut-for-trapezoidal-leadscrew-tr08x15.html
  • Steel TR8x1.5 nuts : http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/linear-motion/117-hex-nut-for-trapezoidal-leadscrew-tr08x15.html
    • Have a great printing experience. 3D Modular Systems
    Evolutive 3D Printers You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
    Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
    Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

description.text: This will house the MACH3 USB HID interface module.

This is a pen cap with connecting features to make geometric shapes including a truncated icosahedron. This item was inspired by other pen cap items on Thingiverse http://www.thingiverse.com/tag:bic 180 pen cap parts assembled make a "BICky ball" (AKA: truncated icosahedron, bucky ball, c60 and buckminsterfullerene) 60 pen cap parts assembled make a dodecahedron. (The last two pictures show the dodecahedrons) The large "BICky ball" was not able to support itself so I had to build it with something to support it on the bottom. (the support is an upside down mini-trampoline covered with a sheet) I uploaded a video of the shapes and the connectors to YouTube http://youtu.be/rWfps0nxLuI The end of the video shows that the caps also mate with Lego small ball joint parts.

I used a CNC mill to make aluminum molds and injection molded polypropylene to make this part. I had to use two separate removable insert in the mold to form the cavities in the cap for the pen and connecting feature.  I cut the aluminum molds with a 1/16 end mill.

comments.text: Beauty! I'm printing this right now for my student's science fair project on aerodynamics. One suggestion I'd like to make is that you orient the car from rear to front along one of the axes, preferably the x. This makes it much easier to scale directly to the desired width, length, etc. in the Makerbot desktop software (as opposed to having to import the .stl into sketchup and measure from there). As it is right now, the model's dimensions in the X axis is not at all what the dimensions from wheel to wheel are. The dimensions of the model in the y-axis is not representative of the car's true front to rear bumper length, etc.

This multipurpose desk pencil sharpener/pencil holder has many sections that are used to hold various things. It also has a cut-out for you to put a really cheap tiny pencil sharpener (like this: http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/71R0je8tlkL._SL1500_.jpg). It would be used in schools, and would be shared by two students at each desk. It uses the screw and peg to clamp onto the edge of each two-person desk between each student. It has a pencil holder in the back, a small notch in the front for miscellaneous things, and two large "pockets" on the sides, also for miscellaneous things. The pencil sharpener slides upside down into the center of the front side, and the pencil shavings fall into the container below. When the container is full of pencil shavings, you have to unscrew the whole thing from the table, hold it over a trashcan, and then slide the door out from underneath so that the shavings fall into the trashcan.

title: Scalar - Upgrade Z Axis SFU1204 Ball screw

description.text:
This thing is a mechanical upgrade for Scalar XL 3D printers.
This upgrade allows to use a SFU 1204 ball crew instead of a standard M8 leadscred on Z Axis. For the convertion, as the Ball screw often requires a special Nut, the ballscrew has to be moved a little bit, for the nut to fit the overall existing design of Scalar XL.

So you wil need to print
  • The bottom Z axis motor holders
  • The Top Z axis smooth rod holders
  • The X axis moto holder
  • The X axis Idler holder

• Top_Z_Holder 8mm.stl is reversible, so you can use it for both right and left side of the printer.
  • Z_SmoothRod_Aligner.stl allows to align the Z smooth rods so that they stay paralelle to the Z Axis extrusion profiles.

We uploaded 2 Gcodes
  • ConfigSFU1204.gcode that allows you to reconfigure the firmware settings of your printer with the proper Zstep/mm (800.00 compatible with SFU1204)
  • ConfigM8.gcode Capable of setting back the Z step/mm (2550) for M8 threaded rod

• M8 + TR08x1.5 Hex nut adaptor: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1379288
    • Have a great printing experience. 3D Modular Systems
    Evolutive 3D Printers You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
    Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
    Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

comments.text:
Right now the only version we have is for 10mm smooth rods.
You can either take the .rsdoc and update the original parts using Design Spark Mechanical (free CAD tool from radiospares) to fit with 8mm smooth rods or use 10mm smooth rods.

print_settings.Printer:: My own design SHAPEOKO based printer

description.text:
This is a Tram Engine based on the Bobber Caboose, but now with the "planks" horizontal like photos of LNER J7. A video of the prototype being tested is here: https://youtu.be/43rY8J1DrOc You can add the "Toby Face" , modified from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:293591, and a driver, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1413975 (here he is enlarged in x and y, to make him a "fat driver!) Four of the wheels are powered, by "TT Motor" gearboxes from EBAY, search for "TT motor Ardunio". They are about £2 each or so. The wheels are to G1MRA guidelines for "standard" wheels on 45mm track. There are also "treaded" wheel versions, that take two 20mm*1mm square cross section rubber bands to improve traction.
(In the photos I did not spot I had fitted three treaded wheels and three standard wheels). UPDATE March 30 2016 : following tests, I would advise changing to the "28mm" diameter wheel to give a bit more clearance, especially on bumpy track and points. I have put the "28mm g1mra" wheel stl in the files. With the rubber tyres, the tram can push about 8 oz, but even with the normal wheels it can still push more than 5 oz, so I would recommend using the normal wheels and not use the rubber tyres unless you have very steep track or lots of carriages to shift. You do not really need the centre, un-driven wheels. If you want to fit "LGB" couplings, or my servo driven one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1000218 , then you will need to cut out a section of the cowcatcher. There is a photo that shows this. I also found on the test run that the cowcatcher did catch on some bumpy track, so there is a second version "Higher CowCatcher" that has a little more clearance, but I would recommend trying changing the wheels to the 28mm versions first. There is also a "slightly smaller steps" stl that makes "slightly smaller" steps that may be easier to fit in the base! I had a lot of problems with the side panels "shearing". I think a heated enclosure around the printer is needed to get these to print well. The base takes 6 AA batteries. The springs and connections came from cheap (ebay) "2AA battery boxes".
In the Video the tram is running from a 2S 2000mAh Lithium cell mounted loosely in the cabin. I do not think that AA batteries would be able to drive the 55mm EDF unit, and the EDF controller can get confused if not fed by a Lithium cell. The motors work well from 3V, so only 2 AA batteries are needed as a minimum to run the Tram nicely, and you can fit these in the boiler if you want. I have found a DC speed controller on Ebay that works well, and the boiler has fittings to take this. But its better to use the 6 AA batteries in the special holder in the base.
The motors, buffers cow catcher etc are held in place by 3mm filament sections.
The lamps are held by 1.75mm filament sections or bits cut from by cocktail sticks .
Screws are "# 4" size, 6.6mm or 13mm. DRILL all the clearance holes to 3mm, and the parts that they screw into out to 2mm before trying to fit the screws!!!
Hopefully the pictures should explain everything else.

Printer:

My own design SHAPEOKO based printer

Rafts:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes: Screws are #4, either 6.5mm (roof and cowcatchers) or 13mm ( for the battery retainers).
Screws are not shown on CAD model!.
DRILL 3mm clearance and 2mm for threads.
parts for AA battery contacts come from a 2 AA switched battery box. see EBAY ."AA Battery Holder Enclosed Box with Switch for 2x AA"
I printed wheels and hubs at 0.10 layers, the rest of the parts were printed at 0.2.
I Used Cura with supports switched on for the roof and cowcatchers and battery retainers.
The rest of the parts were printed without supports, using bare glass, sprayed with 3DLAC.
The sides to the cabin and base ended up very stressed in my print, and have torn after use. I would recommend using a heated enclosure to reduce stress, I have not managed to get a perfect print yet, and you can see in the photos some of the stress cracks, which are worse on the side I did not photograph. I was asked about the hardware so:
The RC receiver gear was Turnigy TGY Ia6, ( bought as a RX/TX set from Hobby king. search "Turnigy TGY-i6 AFHDS Transmitter and 6CH Receiver " I ended up using a 2200mAh battery to power everything. ("Turnigy 2200mAh 2S 20C Lipo Pack "), as it gave longer fan power, unfortunately I have not managed to find a way to hide it neatly in the cab! The fan was "AEO Aircraft 4300KV Brushless Motor 55mm 8 Blade Electric Ducted Fan " (Ebay) For the DC drive motors ("New 4pcs Intelligent Car Gear Motor TT Motor Robot Gear Motor for Arduino") I used either a "Useful 10A Brushed ESC Motor Speed Controller for RC Car Boat Tank without Brake" or "RC ESC 20A Brush Motor Speed Controller+Switchable Brake for RC Car Boat Tank UK" (Ebay) (they were both very similar) . BUT I cut the 5V wire off the servo connector to the RC receiver so that only the Brushless motor controller would be powering the receiver.
For the Brushless Fan motor, I had some failures of the controllers, but any 20A or so Brushless ESC should work. I think the one in the photo that I eventually used was a "RC Model Airplane / Helicopter 30A Brushless Motor Speed Controller ESC SL031" (Ebay). If you want the non RC, non fan version, one of the boiler designs is designed to fit a "New DC 1.8V 3V 5V 6V 12V 2A Low Voltage Motor Speed Controller PWM 1803B (Ebay again!) " DC speed controller, and then the funnel can replace the knob so you can control the tram via the funnel. I treated myself to a Little "Railway" time yesterday after finishing cutting the lawn, and thought I would video the tram blowing some of the rubbish off the lines. Providing I drive SLOWLY.. the tram negotiates the track well, but go too fast and it derails quite easily. I was pleasantly surprised how well it cleared the lines. I had to remove some large branches, but it made cleaning a lot easier and more fun.
I put a video on You tube.. https://youtu.be/_0rxlHB3bGs. I apologise for the very crude station platform, it is a template for one I am working on...

These brackets kept breaking that hold the drawer rails for our kitchen cabinets (see pic of original bracket).  Decided to recreate it as best I could.  I made the walls a little thicker so that they hopefully hold up a little better.  I printed in PLA with 100% infill.  You can play around with the resolution but I used .10mm.
Update 03/01/2016 - Printed one of these out last night at .10mm\100% infill.  Fit was tight but it went on the rail.  What I do is take the rail off, get the bracket started on the end of the rail.  Then tap on the rail a couple times, test fit, tap some more, test fit.  Do this over and over again until you have it seated to the correct length.  Works great.  With all this being said, you may or may not have the same experience printing them at a lower resolution.  It may turn out to be a tighter fit or not fit at all.

This piece is the third design in FreeCAD, and the third "01 Series". It serves to hang, by the end of 1 mm thick, a basic slate of chalks between the drawing surface and the frame, so you can keep handy eraser and chalks to paint.
This piece is a little more complicated than before, so I have not got round the edges properly: some of them have been unable to round them because they do not fit with the surrounding. I think the distribution and amount of elements of the piece (ie primitive cubes that make the design), are not well chosen for subsequent smoothing its edges. Sorry, I have only been 4 days using freecad. ;)
I made it under FreeCad, with Repetier Host and Slic3r, and printed it with a BQ Prusa I3. In the file "Printing Statistics" you can see the parameters of time, weight and length of filament employees. Also print profile used to Slic3r is in the "Rapido" file.

Esta pieza es un poco más complicada que las anteriores, así que no he conseguido redondear los cantos adecuadamente: algunos de ellos no he podido redondearlos porque no encajan con los colindantes. Creo que la distribución y cantidad de elementos que componen la pieza (es decir, los cubos primitivos que componen el diseño), no están bien elegidos para el posterior suavizado de sus aristas. title: Scalar - Compact Nut Adaptors for SFU1204 Holders to M8 + Tr08x1.5 nuts

description.text:
This thing allows to convert 1 nut system into another . For example,
  • You can convert a system using SFU1204 leadscrew into a system using either M8 threaded rod or Tr08x1.5 trapezoidal screw.

For each scenario you will need either a M8 nut or a Tr08x1.5 Hex nut.
Those nuts will be inserted into the adapter making it compatible with the current SFU1204 nut system.

description.header: Update the firmware settings with the provided gcode
description.text:
We uploadeed some Special gcode that will set for you the ZStep/mm for each scenario depending on the Nut you are using.
  • ConfigM8.gcode, will set ZStep/mm to 2560.00
  • ConfigSFU1204.gcode will set ZStep/mm to 800.00
  • ConfigTR08x1.5.gcode will set Zstep/mm to 2133.33

If you are using the Gcode, you might need to save the settings manually into your electronic display. We already included the Save to EEProm gcode commands but for some reasons sometimes the values are not saved properly. Have a great printing experience. 3D Modular Systems

title: MOST Delta printer extruder quick release

description.text: This is a quick release option to allow for easier filament changing on the MOST Delta printer that we made at MTU. This replaces the top piece of the extruder mount, the 2 long M3 bolts & nuts and the piece of rubber tubing. Now I don't have to unscrew the bolts to change filament. Used two 5/32 extension springs 1", held in place with two 5/64" tension pins, in place of M3 bolts. I did have to slightly ream the holes on the extruder mount to fit the springs through, held the ends in place with a couple pieces of metal rod. I shimmed it with a washer as my springs were a little long.

title: Scalar - Compact Nut Adaptors for Trapezoidal Tr08x1.5 Holders to M8 nuts

description.text:
This thing allows to convert 1 nut system into another . For example,
  • You can convert a system using Tr08x1.5 leadscrew into a system using either M8 threaded rod or a Tr08x1.5 Hex nut
• 18th nov 2016: added AdaptorIgusToT8_Nut compatible with chinese Bronze T8 adaptors

For each scenario you will need either a M8 nut or a Tr08x1.5 Hex nut.
Those nuts will be inserted into the adapter making it compatible with the current Tr08x1.5 full nut system.

description.header: Update the firmware settings with the provided gcode
description.text:
We uploadeed some Special gcode that will set for you the ZStep/mm for each scenario depending on the Nut you are using.
  • ConfigM8.gcode, will set ZStep/mm to 2560.00
  • ConfigTR08x1.5.gcode will set Zstep/mm to 2133.33

If you are using the Gcode, you might need to save the settings manually into your electronic display. We already included the Save to EEProm gcode commands but for some reasons sometimes the values are not saved properly. Have a great printing experience. 3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

comments.text:
Actually, let me ask a different question, because I DO have M8 lead screws, but there are TR8x8 trapezoidal screws.
The nut that came with the rods is a Delrin 4-hole - what's the right word... flange?

the easiest way to do is to first design your nut flange.

description.text:
This is a set of basic corners and fittings so that you can use 16mm pvc electrical pipes in your garden. The original idea is from this site where you also can order them if you live in Sweden. The images show some of the many ways that you can use this in your garden, add a fine net around it and you have a perfect way to protect your bushes and trees from birds and other animals. They can also be used to make a small greenhouse or hoop house. I've also added the solidworks files, they are all equation based so if you want to customize the piping diameter etc. just edit it in the equations manager. [UPDATE]
Also added 20mm versions since I got a request for that!

description.text:
Inspired from the awesome OpenR/C Formula 1 car by Daniel Norée;
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1193309 Print:
2x Part A
2x Part B
4x Part C

Printer:

155mm x 95mm + 3Dprinter

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: You need at least 155x95mm build volume for this model. Preferably around 155x250 to get it all in one.

Put part A on the side down and insert the Part B in center of each three-hole-group. Part C goes on the sides. Lastly flip everything over and align the assembled parts into the last Part A and push them together.
Some filing may be required!
This was designed using Autodesk Fusion 360 and using the tyres as measurements from the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1193309 model

comments.text: Dimensions are way off on the bottom 3 mounts, and the only one that fits properly in the top is the center, all others were a loss of filament. I see in your pics that your printer isn't calibrated very well, if you're compensating in the model for the margin of error on your printer, it's not going to work for anyone else. I suggest using either a 1/1 fit, or no more than 100 gap for snug fits, but we're talking whole millimeters too big here. Fitting it would mean grinding completely through entire walls on the tabs. I figured it was over a year later and he must have adjusted it, but of course not.... :(

author: Anti-Quark42

description.text:
This is a spring loaded clip to hold a dial gauge firmly in place when levelling the platform on a Thing-o-matic with a mk 6+ stepstruder.
The gauge bolts to the clip.
The width of the clip, as printed, is 75 mm, so it has to be squeezed to clip into the 70 mm gap that the heated nozzle fits in. The compression keeps the clip secure. This was printed at 50 % infill, it may be that less dense infills will give less spring tension.
I would recommend using this with the power off, to avoid damage.

comments.text: Thanks! I was going to design something that involved removing the extruder to mount the gauge but this is so much better. Need to remove the spare rod end-caps that I installed when I built by bot back in December 2010 as they restrict the Y-axis travel meaning I can't proble the back of the platform, not an issue normally as the extruder is futher back and can reach it but this lies further forward.

description.text:
I designed this set of wings for a casting pattern. The idea is to cast it in aluminium for an insect themed art exhibition. However, it also a great model for a classroom prop.
Based upon : http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Dragonfly.svg
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

There are a few anomolies in the stl but Slic3r and Craftware generated gcode without any problems (Slic3r slow and Craftware super fast). I did however have issues with Skeinforge therefor other slicers may be hit or miss. I would be glad for any feedback.
If you want to create a twist in this wing then gently heat to make the plastic pliable and bend/twist to suit.
There are webbed and hollow stl's for strength or fragility respectively. You can scale up (like these prints) but you may lose detail if scaled down.

remixed_from.title: Turtle Shell Racer High Power Edition

title: Turtle Shell Racer High Power Edition Repaired

description.text:
This is a Repaired set of STL files for the Turtle Shell Racer High Power Edition! Special thanks to Skimbal for the original design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10526). I ran into a problem while finishing the final prints of the SHELL TOP A & B (everything else printed okay). I was able to fix the outdated STL files with netfabb Basic and decided to fix all the files in case others had problems with any STL files (some errors may still exist). I'm building electronics also. I will update with a list when I can. 3/01/16 UPDATE: I added the original PDF instructions for convenience (will make improvements soon), and added 2.8mm filament STLs for attaching the shells together (I didn't have the 3mm filament that was required). 3/06/16 UPDATE: I replaced gear 1 and 3 with new files (also kept the original files) The new gear 1 has a smaller inside diameter of 2mm to fit a 2mm electric motor shaft. The new gear 3 is thicker with a smaller inside diameter for a much better fit. Print all gears with 100% infill so they don't break. I modified the wheelie bar so the dive gear will not hit it. Also added Turtle Shell Racer Assembly and Parts (Updated) PDF! 3/12/16 UPDATE: I purchased all the electronic from Hobbyking.com and have some advise. The gear ratio needs to be tightened up and possible changed. Motor and ESC: (This motor is a little fast for this project, I think they make one with a slightly smaller Kv.)
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__42801__TrackStar_1_18th_Scale_12T_Brushless_power_System_5050kv_USA_warehouse_.html Servo: (I bought the one that was originally recommended, but I would buy this one)
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__36916__Turnigy_8482_TGY_9018MG_MG_Servo_2_5kg_0_10sec_13g_US_Warehouse_.html Battery: (I bought a 3s 35c LiPo, but this was a mistake! Please get a 2s Lipo either a 30c or 35c and around ~2000 to 2500mAh. For example)
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__10273__Turnigy_2450mAh_2S_30C_Lipo_Pack.html The rest of the supplies you can refer to the original electronic PDF. If you're new to Hobbyking.com, please note they have several warehouses to choose from. If they're out of stock in one, they usually have it at another. I got everything from the USA Warehouse West

description.text:
This is a customizable card box, based on zxqueb's awesome design, but with rounded cutouts on the short ends and on the bottom. The end cutouts allow you to more easily draw cards from the deck during gameplay, and the bottom cutout allows you to push up the last couple cards when the deck is running low, as well as identify the deck in the box while it's closed, should you have several similar looking boxes. I have yet to print this, so it is marked "Work in Progress" until I am sure it prints well. (but i think it will) Minor Update 8/22/2013: Split cutout parameters into seperate tab in Customizer
Minor Update 8/22/2013: Tweaked parameters to be whole number % (0-100 instead of 0 to 1), and adjusted parameter usage so the end cutouts can't cut into the sidewall anymore.
I have yet to print this out, but I think it should work fine, since i merely cut out a few pieces of zxqueb's box.  I'll update this once I have printed, however.

author: Vexjets

title: Dual Solids, Morphing a Truncated Dodecahedron into a Triakis Icosahedron-Project 3

description.text:
Nicole Van Oort
02/29/16
George Mason University
Math 493-Mathematics Through 3D Printing
Shows the morphing from the Truncated Dodecahedron to its dual the Triakis Icosahedron.
The Truncated Dodecahedron is one of the 13 Archimedean Solids, meaning it is a convex polyhedron consisting of two or more regular polygons meeting at identical vertices. The Truncated Dodecahedron is composed of 20 triangles faces and 12 decagon faces, with 90 edges and 60 vertices. Polyhedra in general are paired with duels, meaning the faces of one polyhedron correspond to the vertices of another polyhedron. The group of duels to Archimedean solids are known as Catalan solids, first described in 1865 by Eugène Catalan. For the Truncated Dodecahedron, it duel or pair is the Triakis Icosahedron. This polyhedron has 60 isosceles triangle faces, with 90 edges and 32 vertices. Notice that the Truncated Dodecahedron has 32 faces, and the Triakis Icosahedron has 32 vertices. Also the Truncated Dodecahedron has 60 vertices while the Triakis Icosahedron has 60 faces. Thus the relationship between the faces and vertices of duels can be seen numerically. The way one can obtain a polyhedron's duel from the polyhedral itself are various. The method I used is Truncation. This means that the vertices of the original polyhedron are continuously chopped or shortened towards the midpoint, until the original faces of the polyhedron disappear and the duel emerges. This is due to the fact, that a regular polygon uniformly truncated (truncated equally at each vertex) will become another regular polygon. The term truncation originates from the term "truncated" used by Johannes Kepler for the truncated Archimedean solids that he rediscovered in 1620, after originally being discussed by Archimedes and Pappus. (The Archimedean Solids were thought to be first described by Archimedes, although only heard through second hand sources. Kepler finally reconstructed the entire set in a book he wrote "The World Harmony.")
One benefit of choosing the truncation method is that mathematica has a truncation function under its Polyhedron Operations package. It also has multiple well known polyheda under its PolyhedronData package that allows you to produce 3D images of multiple polyhedrons with one command. Thus 3 of our 4 solids used to display the morphing of the Truncated Polyhedron to the Triakis Icosahedron were obtained readily through mathematica to be exported as an STL file into makerbot. The first step was to import the command "Needs[PolyhedronOperations]" into mathematica, calling in the further polyhedra commands we need to continue. Then to produce the first step of our morphing, or the original Truncated Dodecahedron we have two options. The first is to use the command "PolyhedronData["TruncatedDodecahedron"] to call the Truncated Dodecahedron directly. The other method, which can be seen in the mathematica image below uses the Truncate operation, brought in through the PolyhedronOperations package to truncate the Dodecahedron into the Truncated Dodecahedron. Secondly, to begin the initial truncation process, we can now truncate the Truncated Dodecahedron further to get the first step of morphing through truncation. This produces a polyhedron with circular faces instead of decagons. The other nice feature about the Truncate command is it allows you to specify the ratio of truncation you want from 0 to 0.5, where 0.5 means the polyhedron is halfway truncated towards its duel. I utilized 0.3 as my ratio to truncate about a third of the way to the duel. This code can be found below. Lastly I used mathematica and the Polyhedron Data command to obtain a 3D image of the Triakis Icosahedron duel, which is a stored polyhedron included in the database of mathematica. To get these three polyhedron into STL files that can be inserted into MakerBot, the Export command is used, specifying to export a .stl file. The issue with the Truncate command in mathematica is that it doesn't allow truncation past the halfway point, thus to get to two-thirds of the way to my duel (to break the morphing process into 4 steps/solids) I needed to utilize OpenSCAD instead. To grasp an idea of the polyhedron I was looking for, I utilized the Stella4D Demo software and its truncate tool that allowed me to visualize and scroll from the original Truncated Dodecahedron to its duel and back. Finding 0.6 percent of truncation using the software I obtained the image of the polyhedron I was looking for in OpenSCAD. In order to obtain this polyhedron, I imported the STL files of the Truncated Dodecahedron and Triakis Icosahedron into OpenSCAD. The key is the idea that the faces of one are the edges of the other, thus the Triakis Icosahedron needed to be rotated until its vertices were in the middle of the Truncated Dodecahedron's faces in order for the truncation to work properly. Then using the intersection command, which correlates to truncation of polyhedron because you are cutting of the edges of the larger polyhedron (truncated dodecahedron) until it meets up with the edges of the smaller polyhedron (traikis icosahedron), I intersected the Triakis Icosahedron with the Truncated Dodecahedron to truncate the Truncated Dodecahedron. As you can see in the OpenSCAD image below, I had to play around with the proper numbers until I got a polyhedron that resembled the polyhedron I had generated in the Stella4D Demo tool, or that polyhedron two-thirds truncated. Thus when I observed this polyhedron, I also rendered it to an STL file.
Finally I combined all 4 STL files into one .thing file in MakerBot, equally scaled them and then exported it to be printed.
The code and equations for this project were straightforward thanks to the ease in use of the Polyhedron Operations package in Mathematica. If confusion ever arises about the Mathematica code to use, the Mathematica help window provides excellent instructions. All the STL files for each step of the morph, as well as the Mathematica and OpenSCAD files of the polyhedron too are found under thing files.
Citations:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archimedean_solid
http://www.software3d.com/PolyNav/PolyNavigator.php#morph

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: This print took a total of 4 hours and 5 minutes, when all 4 solids were printed together under the same .thing file. If each solid is created as a separate STL file like mine were, using MakerBot and the Add command, all four solids can be inserted into the same MakerBot file to print.

This is the mathematica code to produce the initial Truncated Dodecahedron. This is the mathematica code to create the first morph of the Truncated Dodecahedron through truncation. The second morphing of the Truncated Dodecahedron through truncation was created by importing the Truncated Dodechaedron and Triakis Icosahedron files exported from mathematica as STL files, then using the intersection command. Expiermenting with the sizes of each solid was required until the right numbers were found that created the image above. This is the mathematica code used to create the dual of the Truncated Dodecahedron, the Triakis Icosahedron.

author: JDN

description.text:
Steampunk-ish goggles designed to work with 52mm camera lens filters. These are prototypes. The finished design is almost complete, but I wanted to get something of the final design posted before Dragon*Con. The octopus on the side of the blue strap shield didn't print too well at 0.2mm layer height on my boss's Replicator2, but with some handwork, it should turn out ok.
If you buy 52mm color filter camera lenses from Amazon, they will fit in the front. I need to do some redesign so that the filters will fit snugly in the tube. Currently they need to be glued into place, which is a bummer, but they sure do look nifty.
Aug 25:
Put together the goggles after painting+sealing them. They look good, although I think I'm going to have to reprint the top tube and redesign it so the filter sits inside comfortably. We'll see how it goes!
Aug 26: Replaced the previous top-tube piece with a new one. It snugly holds the 52mm filter I bought (I based it on the lens I ordered from Amazon - search for Goja camera lens filter and it'll show up).

I printed 9 pieces in total - two wings, two lens holders, two front tube pieces, two buckles, and one bridge/nose-piece. The goggles are symmetric (no left-right) and are assembled using 2.5M x 30 or 35mm long bolts and nuts (which can be ordered from McMaster-Carr if your Lowes or Home Depot doesn't carry them).
I designed a few different-length bridges. I found that the 20mm bridge is best for me, but I'm not petite. One of the smaller ones might work better for smaller people.
The octopus on the side didn't print perfectly, but I enjoyed making it. I've got some variations in mind for future updates.
I used Valspar Primer for Plastics spray (2 coats) and will use Testers Enamel model paint to get the proper look.
I will use 25mm (1inch) elastic straps for these goggles (that's a blatant borrow from guyc's excellent steampunk goggles - see the derived from section for a link).

comments.text: I tried setting inches, even went into 3ds max and loaded in inches, i dont know what program u used to model them, but it messed them all up. Makerware, mPrint, Slic3r, Kiss, Cura, even friggen S3d, wont size them correctly. Cura trys but from what i can tell, you either modeled at the wrong decimal place, or you converted them to another format at some point and forgot to tell ti the sizing info. Kind of upsetting. Ive tried the 25.4x, which is too big. Ive tried 10x, which is too small. Now i have to go into max manually and size them correctly, which is going to chew up the better part of today. :( Theres a reason we use millimeters here in the FDM field, man. I'm in the US too... I get it, but you need to know both... Would be nice if you uploaded a fixed version.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text:
@DevWolf - 2 things:
1) I did design these parts in millimeters. The goggles are designed to fit 52mm camera lens filters (that's a good way to check the proper scaling, btw). I uploaded the STL files I made in SolidWorks which (literally) were designed in mm. Unfortunately thingiverse/makerware goofed the units, meaning that I (and others) had to scale them in makerware (gasp) with the mm -> inches conversion button.
2) lulz are you serious? I'm sorry that my free design on the free website aren't working for you.
Given that several other people have printed these goggles without complaint (including me), I think the problem might be on your end.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: I know how to scale it man, but in order to get that correct, ive had to take it into 3ds and mock up a bunch of stuff to size it to, like the lens. If you had just modeled it with correct size information, none of this would have been an issue. As far as thingiverse, it has nothing to do with size units, it just transfers YOUR file. And makerware isnt even in the equation. Maybe on your end but if youre running it through makerware before uploading, i dont know what youre trying to accomplish. The scale conversion method does not work, because the part is, as i would describe it, microscopic for a model. Its way too small for it to have been a mm vs inch thing, theres something else going on. As for the lulz, i find it funny that you think it bothers me that i cant print it, im an engineer dude, i make my own stuff. Its the 9.5 out of 10 people not knowing what theyre doing thing, thats what irritates me. As far as other people making them, yes, but theyre still not sized right. And notice how many other people have had problems... Your comments are filled with it, so nice try there, but no, not really. Ive been doing this for 10 years, printing for 7, with 2 grad degrees, running a business doing this every day, 7 days a week, sometimes 14 hours a day, and i dont have these problems with anything else.... I highly doubt its on my end, but if you have a better explanation than "makerware and thingiverse did it!" then i would love to hear it...
comments.author: DAstronomer

comments.text: These are so spiffy. I want to make them!
comments.author: MonkeyRobot22

comments.text: I want to make some simulated pressure/temperature gages and the front pieces of your goggles would do the trick if they fit the lenses I already have. They are from a pair of welding goggles and are the same size as a number of goggle inserts I have obtained from steampunk dealers so I assume they are a standard size. Your goggles are designed for 52mm photography lenses but my lenses measure 50mm. They also lack the thread mount that the camera lenses have. Will my lenses fit without modification or will I need to scale the goggles when they go to the printer?
comments.author: Kordite

comments.text:
Hi Kordite, I seem to have lost my design files for this particular set of goggles, but I have the lenses with me.
The outer diameter of the lens holder (ie the inner diameter of the goggles) is something like 52.4mm where the threaded part is. The non-threaded part is more like 55mm (that's what sticks out beyond the lens in the main photo for this Thing).
I would definitely scale down to 95.4% or so - play around with the goggles and make sure they fit. The part that I used to hold the lens is lens-holder-octopus.stl. Print a few of those with the scaling near 95.4% and see what works best for you.
Cheers,
DAstronomer

comments.text: Tried to print but getting a lot of stringing from overhangs. Did yours string?
comments.author: SvenEDT

comments.text:
I had some stringing on the interior where the cut-outs for the straps are (the 'wing' piece), but it wasn't too bad. I used some medium-grit sandpaper and it came off for the most part.
I didn't have any noticeable stringing from the other pieces...unless you're referring to the support material that's so freaking hard to get off...
I printed all of the pieces with the flat (or flattest) side down. Apparently I chose my initial build plane poorly when I started, so I had to turn them in Makerware before printing. The 'lens-holder' piece took a lot of support material, but I didn't notice much stringing there.
Hope this helps!

title: HV supply bracket for discharge tubes

description.text:
I needed a bunch of brackets to hold small high voltage supplies in place for a rack of discharge (spectral emission) tubes I have. 
I got the tubes at an antique store, and wired up a separate ~2kv supply for each. There's also a TTL signal to control the bank from a microcontroller. 
This was my first project with Alibre cad, to make it parametric. I found it a great tool to use, and it's now my method of choice.

title: Z Axis Motor Bracket for Folger Prusa i3 (Acrylic Frame)

description.text:
I was wondering how to get a more stable acylic frame for my Folger Prusa i3 so, I designed this "Z motor bracket" and, it works pefect!
There is just one .stl file and the only thing you have to do is to get it "mirrored" using that feature on your favourite slicer software to get the other side.
Please notice on the picture that the bracket is not designed to be flush with the table surface, you have to use one flat washer (or more) to install this bracket. This allowed me to do some  adjustments if they were needed to get the frame absolutely vertical.

I modified this to add a mount for the extruder head on a Replicator 1. Corner supports snap off easily. The piece friction fits, and angled correctly, the Sharpie markers do not get in the way of the cables.

comments.text: I've got a Replicator 2, and I'm wondering if this would fit. I also wonder how you've mounted the filament stress-relief tube (through which the filament goes) to the colorizer...
comments.author: GaetaWoo

comments.text: I can't say whether it would fit on a 2. We've got a 1 and 2X. It does not fit on the 2X, because of the plastic hood on top.
comments.author: GaetaWoo

comments.text: Great remix! I have never tried the obvious black sharpie, how does it come out?
comments.author: ramai

comments.text: It comes out pretty nicely! Given the "mixing" effect, with natural ABS it comes out something like a medium-dark grey. So far, blue is the best luck I've had. My reds keeps coming out orange.
comments.author: ramai

comments.text: Yeah, I've got the same issue with red. I love how green comes out, especially on transparent.
comments.author: rbuckbailey

comments.text: I tried something similar. How do you keep the sharpies from popping out on retraction? I was thinking I needed to do something like the rubber band solution that someone else came up with.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: So far, gravity has done the job. I've had them pop out on me while incautiously reloading filament, but not yet during a print.
comments.author: cymon
